ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Definitely take this class it is really interesting and actually very applicable to many current situations outside of the Balkans. You basically just talk about nationality and identity theory. Assignments are reasonable and Greenberg is perhaps the nicest man you'll ever meet.
I don't think it's being offered again.

At the beginning of the course, you do know feel nearly qualified enough to contribute to a meaningful discussion about the former Yugoslavia. However, with each week's readings and videos building on one another, you feel by the end to be quite conversant in topics related to the break up of Yugoslavia, and more generally about the politics of language and identity.Would definitely recommend this course, but unfortunately Professor Greenberg is leaving!

Truly an end of an era. So much interesting material, coupled with a professor who was amazingly caring, spirited, and knowledgeable. Whoever takes on this course next will surely have big shoes to fill!
A good class, though with Professor Greenberg being gone, it likely will not be offered anymore.
Good course on the Balkans. Take it if interested in language issues.
It is a great discussion about the Balkans. I would recommend it to anyone looking to learn more about the breakup of Yugoslavia.
